ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly virtual thesis writing meetings.
Readings, peer discussion groups and lab meeting virtually.
N/A
I would meet with my advisor every week to discuss my thesis ideas and receive feedback on the work that I had done.

I was able to conduct experiments in person, but almost all meetings (e.g. lab meetings, meetings with advisor) were conducted virtually. Some of my work was also done remotely if I did not need to go into lab.
8-12 hours of virtual research work each week

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This lab helped me learn how to read and dissect empirical writing.
Deeper understanding of topics explored in the area of comparative cognition
My ability to find papers related to topics I am interested in improved greatly, and by working with Vlad I have been working on how to present our research in a coherent manner.
Experience in designing and conducting independent research -- good opportunity to see a project all the way through from generating the idea to writing up the results of a study.
I gained a lot of technical and wet lab skills, including immunohistochemistry, brain sectioning, and rodent surgeries.
Learned more about the field of psychology, different statistical methods, how to do literature reviews and write reports

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that this course did a great job of introducing me to the field of canine cognition. Ellen, the lab manager, was so kind, accommodating and willing to answer any and I question that I had.
Obviously it can be hard to stay engaged in a virtual lab setting, but I think having multiple meetings per week was very effective in keeping students involved.
Strengths: the course is very flexible in that it can be tailored toward specific circumstances, so I was able to work at a pace that was relevant for the project and learn things that interested me.

Strengths - good mentor system, able to learn a lot despite virtual environment, flexibility 

Weaknesses - none

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the lab did its best to accommodate its practices during the pandemic. I thought that the peer discussion groups were really helpful and helped me get to know members of the lab in a small group setting.
The extra meetings were extremely helpful.
Meeting with my advisor each week, emailing back and forth daily, and getting feedback on the work that I completed.
Being able to go into lab was a large success because most of my work needed to be done in person, so I appreciated that undergraduates were allowed back into lab spaces!
Weekly/bi-weekly meetings with mentor; presentation for entire lab at the end of the semester. Perhaps meetings more often would be useful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!  If you are interested in having an introduction to lab work and also interested in the field of comparative cognition, this is the lab for you!
Yes! I love my role at the lab and would encourage anyone else who is interested to become involved.
Of course, if you have research you are interested in and an advisor to work with you should absolutely pursue it.
Yes, for anyone who's interested in research, it's a really good chance to get hands-on experience working closely with a professor.

Yes, great opportunity to build your lab skills as you're able to get relatively invested into a project if working 8-12 hours a week but you're also able to work on your own schedule for those 8-12 hours.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in psych research and want to develop writing and statistical skills.
